Wait, the problem says the trait has a fitness of 0.6, meaning that its relative fitness is 0.6 compared to the wild type. So, the wild type would have fitness 1, and the mutant has fitness 0.6. But since the trait is dominant, the fitness depends on whether at least one copy is mutated. So, the average fitness of the population would be calculated based on the frequency of the mutant allele. Assuming Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, the frequency of the mutant allele is p=1/8000≈0.000125, and the heterozygote and homozygous dominant would also carry the mutation. Each such genotype has a fitness of 0.6, while the homozygous wild-type has a fitness of 1. So, the mean fitness (w̄) would be: w̄ = p^2 * 1 + 2pq * 0.6 + q^2 * 1.

Since p is very small, q ≈ 1. So, w̄ ≈ (1/8000)^2 * 1 + 2*(1/8000)*(7999/8000)*0.6 + (7999/8000)^2 *1. But this will simplify to approximately 0 + (2/8000)*0.6 + 1 ≈ 0.00015 + 1 ≈ 1.00015. So, the mean fitness is roughly 1. Thus, the change in allele frequency due to selection can be approximated by Δp = [p^2 * (1 - 1)] + [2pq * (0.6 - 1)] + [q^2 * (1 - 1)] ] / w̄ ≈ [ -2pq * 0.4 ] / 1 ≈ -0.8pq. This leads to Δp ≈ -0.8*(1/8000)*(7999/8000) ≈ -0.8/(8000^2) ≈ -8e-8. To counteract this change, the mutation rate must create alleles that increase their fitness. The mutation rate μ contributes μ * 1 to the mutant allele, increasing its proportion. The equilibrium condition occurs when the increase from mutation equals the decrease from selection. So, μ * 1 = |Δp|. From above, Δp ≈ -8e-8, so μ ≈ 8e-8. Converting to scientific notation, that's 8e-8, which isn't among the options.
